summary: seasonal, pandemic, and zoonotic influenza viruses cause annual epidemics during autumn and winter in temperate regions. they predominantly cause upper respiratory tract disease with rare extension to the lower respiratory tract, resulting in severe and even fatal pneumonia. zoonotic influenza viruses, like the pandemic H1N1 virus in 2009, cause sporadic pandemics with variable mortality. our results showed that, at 4 days post inoculation, pH1N1 caused pneumonia intermediate in severity between that caused by seasonal H1N1 and HPAI H5N1. this was associated with virus replication throughout the lower respiratory tract for pH1N1, while seasonal H1N1 replicated mainly in the bronchi. however, the location of virus replication and extent and severity of associated pathological changes were recorded at a single time point. trachea-bronchial lymph nodes were slightly enlarged between 0.5 and 4 dpi, with a peak on 1 dpi in the nasal swabs. the mean body weight loss was around 10% (Figure 1d) on gross pathology, a few dark red and raised areas were seen in the lungs of some animals and were consistent with mild pulmonary consolidation. 0 0 0 0 0 0 1.5 (1–2) staining. antigen expression in the nose was present from 0.5 to 4 dpi. no antigen expression was seen in the tracheal, bronchial, bronchiolar, and tracheo-bronchial glandular epithelium at any time point. antigen expression and histopathology of nasal respiratory epithelium of ferrets inoculated with different influenza viruses. there is high antigen expression with associated lesions characterized by neutrophilic rhinitis in the olfactory epithelium of ferrets inoculated with pH1N1 on 1 and 4 dpi. there is high antigen expression with associated lesions characterized by bronchiolitis in bronchiolar epithelium of ferrets inoculated with different influenza viruses. for H5N1 there was no expression on 1 dpi and moderate antigen expression with associated lesions on 4 dpi. blood follow the same pattern for H3N2 and pH1N1. for pH1N1 there is a peak of neutrophils in the alveoli on 0.5 dpi followed by a dip and a response of myelopoiesis in the blood. the high demand for neutrophils in the alveoli is not followed by higher release of neutrophils in the blood. viral excretion of H3N2 could be directly estimated based on viral production scores in the nose and trachea. this suggests that these regions were the main sources of excreted virus. the trachea-bronchial lymph nodes were enlarged from 0.5 to 7 dpi. there was a mild to severe multifocal rhinitis and bronchiolitis. the trachea-bronchial lymph nodes were enlarged from 0.5 to 7 dpi, with a peak on 7 dpi. the tracheo-bronchial lymph nodes and tonsils demonstrated lymphadenopathy. in the palatine roof of two animals there was severe inflammation and necrosis of the sero-mucous glands. on 0.5 dpi there was infiltration of neutrophils in the bronchiolar epithelium and lumen with mild peribronchiolar cuffing. on 1 dpi the number of neutrophils increased with necrosis of the epithelium, intraluminal cellular debris and peribronchiolar cuffing. on 2 dpi the necrosis was more severe than on 1 dpi. the high values decreased after 1 dpi consistent with the severe damage of the epithelium. the tracheo-bronchial lymph nodes and tonsils did not express virus antigen. there was no virus antigen expression in extra-respiratory tissues. on 14 dpi, the numbers of neutrophils and mononuclear cells were decreased in both the blood and the alveoli. excretion of pH1N1 was a positive linear function of viral production in the upper regions of the respiratory tract (nose and trachea) as a significant predictor. by gross pathology, there was multifocal pulmonary consolidation on 0.5 dpi. on 1 dpi, there was fluid in the bronchi and lung parenchyma. on 2 dpi, the percentage of affected lung tissue had increased dramatically to almost 60%. antigen expression in the trachea was present from 0.5 to 3 dpi. antigen expression in the alveoli was present in type II pneumocytes and less in type I pneumocytes and alveolar macrophages. virus titers on 1 dpi were higher than expected based on virus antigen expression in the nose. this could be due to slower replication on 0.5 dpi and necrosis of virus-replicating cells on 4 dpi. highest virus titers were seen on 2 dpi in olfactory bulb and jejunum. viral production and damage in the deeper regions of the respiratory tract (bronchi, bronchioles and alveoli; P = 0.018 and P = 0.024, respectively); their product (P = 0.025); damage in the upper regions of the respiratory tract (nose and trachea; P = 0.001); its product with viral production in these regions (P = 0.002); and its product with viral production in these regions (P = 0.031) Figure 9. generalized linear models used to define possible predictors of viral excretion. these models were used to determine significant linear relationships between these scores and viral excretion. excretion of H3N2 was a positive linear function of viral production in the upper regions of the respiratory tract. URRTViral production in DRRT 0.049 0.01 9.2 0.002 Damage in URRTViral production in DRRT 0.049 0.02 4.6 0.031 URRT: upper regions of the respiratory tract (nose and trachea); DRRT: deeper regions of the respiratory tract (bronchi, bronchioles and alveoli). there was a mild splenomegaly from 0.5 to 14 dpi. there was a mild to severe multifocal rhinitis and bronchiolitis. in the lungs, there was a mild to severe multifocal bronchitis and bronchiolitis with intra-epithelial and intraluminal neutrophils. on 3 dpi there were both new lesions with acute necrosis and old lesions with type II hyperplasia present. on 4 dpi the type II hyperplasia and hypertrophy was more pronounced. on 7 dpi there was severe epithelial hyperplasia and hypertrophy as well as intraluminal edema and hemorrhage. antigen expression in the nose was present from 0.5 to 7 dpi starting on 0.5 dpi in the respiratory epithelium and on 1 dpi in the olfactory epithelium. in the trachea there was antigen expression from 0.5 to 6 dpi in the bronchi and bronchioles from 0.5 to 7 dpi with peak values on 1 dpi. the extra-respiratory tissues, virus was isolated from the olfactory bulb, cerebellum, cerebrum, and heart. on 1 dpi, there was an increase of neutrophils in the blood and in the alveoli. on 2 dpi, there was an increase of neutrophils in the blood and in the alveoli. an increase in body temperature was seen with a peak on 1 dpi. the mean body weight loss was up to 15% on 7 dpi. by gross pathology, multifocal pulmonary consolidation was seen on 0.5 dpi with grey-red raised, and slightly firmer than normal areas. on 2 dpi the percentage of affected lung tissue decreased again. tracheo-bronchial lymph nodes and tonsils demonstrated lymphadenopathy. in the palatine roof of two animals there was severe inflammation and necrosis of the sero-mucous glands. on 0.5 dpi there was mild DAD that was characterized by neutrophils in the alveolar walls. on 1 dpi the number of neutrophils increased with necrosis of the epithelium. on 2 dpi the necrosis was more severe than on 1 dpi. on 4 dpi there was increased epithelial hyperplasia with moderate cuffing. nodes and tonsils did not express virus antigen while glandular epithelial cells in the palatine roof of two animals did express antigen on 7 dpi. digital scoring showed that the amount of air-containing tissue was comparable for all days with averages between 63 and 77%. excretion of pH1N1 was a positive linear function of viral production in the upper regions of the respiratory tract (nose and trachea) the final GLM predicting excretion of pH1N1 included only viral production in the upper regions of the respiratory tract (nose and trachea) as a significant predictor. on 1 dpi, there was fluid in the bronchi and lung parenchyma. on 2 dpi, the percentage of affected lung tissue had increased dramatically to almost 60%. relative lung weights were increased on all time points and were much higher than in the other virus groups. antigen expression in the trachea was present from 0.5 to 3 dpi, predominantly on 1 dpi. antigen expression in the alveoli was present in type II pneumocytes. it was seen from 0.5 to 4 dpi with large percentages from 1 to 3 dpi. virus titers on 1 dpi were higher than on the other days. this could be due to slower replication on 0.5 dpi and necrosis of virus-replicating cells on 4 dpi. highest virus titers were seen on 2 dpi in olfactory bulb and jejunum. damage in the upper regions of the respiratory tract (nose and trachea; P = 0.001); its product with viral production in these regions (P = 0.002); its product with viral production in these regions (P = 0.031). a negative linear function of each of the three single predictors and a positive linear function of each of the three products. on 1 dpi, there was fluid in the bronchi and lung parenchyma. on 2 dpi, the percentage of affected lung tissue had increased dramatically. the relative lung weights were increased on all time points and were much higher than in the other virus groups. antigen expression in the trachea was present from 0.5 to 3 dpi. antigen expression in the alveoli was present in type II pneumocytes. it was seen from 0.5 to 4 dpi with large percentages from 1 to 3 dpi. in the lungs, virus titers on 1 dpi were higher than on the other days. this could be due to slower replication on 0.5 dpi and necrosis of virus-replicating cells on 4 dpi. highest virus titers were seen on 2 dpi in olfactory bulb and jejunum. control group with inoculum Clinical signs and gross pathology No clinical signs were seen and there was a survival rate of 100%. by gross pathology, the lungs had few dark red and slightly raised areas consistent with mild pulmonary consolidation. the relative lung weight remained constant at around 0.6% on all time points. in blood and alveolar lumina No trends were observed in total leucocyte, segmented neutrophil, mononuclear cell and lymphocyte counts in the blood, or in comparison of leucocyte counts between blood and alveolar lumina. clinical signs and gross pathology No clinical signs were seen and there was a survival rate of 100%. by gross pathology, the lungs had few dark red and slightly raised areas consistent with mild pulmonary consolidation. time course experiments show how strongly the spatial and temporal dynamics of infection and associated lesions in the ferret respiratory tract differ between a seasonal human influenza virus (H3N2) and a pandemic human influenza virus (pH1N1). the associated lesions followed the same spatial distribution as virus infection, but their severity peaked between 1 and 6 days later. the main source of excreted virus likely differs between H3N2 and H5N1 infections, based on comparison of virus tit the final GLM for H3N2 viral excretion revealed only viral production in the upper regions of the respiratory tract as significant predictor. the lower respiratory tract is the main source of excreted H5N1, at least until 3 dpi. however, the final GLM for pH1N1 viral excretion revealed that only the viral production in the nose and trachea was a significant predictor of viral excretion. in the current study, we found very little H3N2 infection in any cell types of the ferret lower respiratory tract. this suggests that other factors were necessary for H3N2 to infect these cell types. in the current study, we found abundant H5N1 infection in alveolar and bronchiolar epithelial cells. thelial cells became infected despite the relatively weak attachment of H5N1 to the latter cell types. different parameters were used to measure the severity of lower respiratory tract disease in our ferrets. relative lung weight and affected lung tissue allowed the best quantitative distinction between the virus groups. immunohistochemistry (%) Percentage of antigen expression in the alveoli. alveolar epithelial damage was visible as hypertrophy and hyperplasia of type II pneumocytes, which was maximal at 7 dpi. by 14 dpi the damage to and inflammation of the alveoli was completely resolved, except for a remnant of mononuclear cells in the alveolar lumina, and virus infection was no longer detectable. this could be explained by a higher induction of pro-inflammatory cytokine production (IL-6 and IL-8) in the lower respiratory tract of ferrets infected with H5N1 but not with pH1N1. another major difference with pH1N1 infection was the low influx of mononuclear cells, with a mononuclear cell count of less than half that in pH1N1 infection by 4 dpi. increase of neutrophils in the blood at 1 dpi correlates with influx of neutrophils into the alveolar lumina. lack of increase in monocytes corresponds with failure of the acute inflammatory response in the lungs to transform into a more chronic inflammatory response. this is corroborated by the presence of immature neutrophils with rod-shaped nuclei in the blood. the implication of these sites of replication for the pathogenesis and transmission of these viruses is yet to be elucidated. the extensive H5N1 infection in extra-respiratory tissues known from previous studies [11], [28], [27], [30] likely occurs by spread from the respiratory tract via the blood [24], [31], [32]. three viruses were used: seasonal H3N2 virus (A/Netherlands/177/2008), isolated from a patient during the 2008 influenza season [34] and pandemic 2009 virus (pH1N1) (A/Netherlands/602/2009), isolated from a specimen of a human patient who had recently visited Mexico during the pandemic in 2009 [35]. the virus was chosen as a representative virus from a recent seasonal H3N2 influenza epidemic. the cells were grown up to a monolayer of 80 to 90% in two 75 cm2 flasks (A and B) the cells were incubated for 2 days at 37°C. to mimic cellular damage in MDCK cells during virus infection we aimed to reach a cytopathic effect (CPE of 75%) ferrets received atipamezole hydrochloride (0.5 mg/kg Antisedan; Orion Pharma, Espoo Finland) after inoculation, the ferrets were monitored daily for clinical signs until maximum 14 dpi. the animals were predestined to be sacrificed at 12 hours (0.5 day), 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 and 14 dpi (for H5N1 not at 7 and 14 dpi) pH1N1 (A/Netherlands/602/2009), H5N1 (A/Indonesia/02/2005) and Aleutian disease virus were maintained in standard housing. animals were anesthetized with ketamine and medetomidine hydrochloride. temperature logger (DST micro-T ultra small temperature logger; Star-Oddi, Reykjavik, Iceland) recorded the body temperature of the animals every 10 min. four animals per time point were euthanized by exsanguination under ketamine/medetomidine anesthesia at 12 hours (0.5 day), 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 or 14 dpi. the trachea was clamped off to prevent the lungs from deflating upon opening the thoracic cavity, allowing visual estimation of the area of affected lung parenchyma. four slides with longitudinal section or cross-section of cranial or caudal lobes per animal were performed on every slide. for the extent of alveolitis, bronchiolitis, bronchitis, and tracheitis we scored: 0, no inflammatory cells; 1, few inflammatory cells; 2, moderate numbers of inflammatory cells; 3, many inflammatory cells. s were identified on the basis of their morphology and location. large, oval to round cells with a distinct cell border, foamy cytoplasm and large, oval to bean-shaped nucleus were located in the alveolar lumen separate from the alveolar wall. a cat infected experimentally with H5N1 was used as positive control. the images were 1024768 pixels with 0.455 m per pixel. the percentage of air-containing space present in the pulmonary tissue was calculated as 100%. the quantity of virus replication was calculated either as the percentage of antigen expression (red staining) relative to quantity of tissue (blue staining) total leucocyte counts were determined in blood collected in EDTA Vacutainer tubes. blood was stained with may-Grünwald-Giemsa (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) generalized linear models were used to determine the most appropriate predictors of viral excretion for each virus based on viral production and damage in the respiratory tract. the results were considered significant when P0.05. three viruses were used: seasonal H3N2 virus (A/Netherlands/177/2008), isolated from a patient during the 2008 influenza season [34] and pandemic 2009 virus (pH1N1) (A/Netherlands/602/2009), isolated from a specimen of a human patient who had recently visited Mexico during the pandemic in 2009 [35]. the virus was chosen as a representative virus from a recent seasonal H3N2 influenza epidemic. the cells were grown up to a monolayer of 80 to 90% in two 75 cm2 flasks (A and B) the cells were incubated for 2 days at 37°C. to mimic cellular damage in MDCK cells during virus infection we aimed to reach a cytopathic effect (CPE) of 75%. ferrets received atipamezole hydrochloride (0.5 mg/kg Antisedan; Orion Pharma, Espoo Finland) after inoculation, the ferrets were monitored daily for clinical signs until maximum 14 dpi. the animals were predestined to be sacrificed at 12 hours (0.5 day), 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 and 14 dpi (for H5N1 not at 7 and 14 dpi) ferrets were anesthetized with ketamine and medetomidine hydrochloride. temperature logger was placed in the peritoneal cavity. effect of virus infection on body temperature was based on changes in daily average of maximum body temperatures per virus group. four animals per time point were euthanized by exsanguination under ketamine/medetomidine anesthesia at 12 hours (0.5 day), 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 or 14 dpi. the trachea was clamped off to prevent the lungs from deflating upon opening the thoracic cavity, allowing visual estimation of the area of affected lung parenchyma. four slides with longitudinal section or cross-section of cranial or caudal lobes per animal were assessed. for the extent of alveolitis, bronchiolitis, bronchitis, and tracheitis we scored: 0, no inflammatory cells; 1, few inflammatory cells; 2, moderate numbers of inflammatory cells. alveolar macrophages were identified on the basis of their morphology and location. large, oval to round cells with a distinct cell border, foamy cytoplasm and large, oval to bean-shaped nucleus. tissues were stained with a primary antibody against the influenza A nucleoprotein as described previously. the images were 1024768 pixels with 0.455 m per pixel. the percentage of air-containing space present in the pulmonary tissue was calculated as 100% minus the total percentage of pulmonary tissue (blue staining) the quantity of virus replication was calculated either as the percentage of antigen expression (red staining) relative to quantity of tissue (blue staining) blood was collected in EDTA Vacutainer tubes using an automated hematology analyser. total leucocyte counts were determined by counting 100 cells per slide. the numbers of lymphocytes, mononuclear cells, blastocytes, rod-shaped neutrophils, segmented neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils and normoblasts were calculated. generalized linear models were used to determine the most appropriate predictors of viral excretion for each virus, based on viral production and damage in the respiratory tract. the results were considered significant when P0.05.
